preface.title: Welcome!

blockquote.title: Mission
blockquote.para: The DocCookBook project aims to create a collection of cookbook-style solutions released under a Creative Commons (CC) license for the international DocBook community.

preface.para: According to its homepage, DocBook is a schema (available in several languages including RELAX NG, SGML and XML DTDs, and W3C XML Schema) maintained by the DocBook Technical Committee of OASIS. It is particularly well suited to books and papers about computer hardware and software (though it is by no means limited to these applications).

Although there are helpful and valuable documentation―be it as a book
Like the reference DocBook 5: The Definitive Guide from Norman Walsh or Bob Stayton 's DocBook XSL or online
Dave Pawson maintains a DocBook FAQ ―I always felt there is a gap. This gap could be bridged with a guide that only concentrates on problems and their solution in a concise manner. Until now nobody wrote a book that combines possible problems, pitfalls, how to do this, and the benefits in a cookbook style. My book is intented to be such a book. However, to be clear, it does not seek to replace any other information, be it a printed or an online resource. It aims for enhancing the world of DocBook with a different view.

This book is a collection of topics, specific to a certain problem written mostly as step-by-step instructions. It covers very easy topics or demanding ones
The difficulty can range from very easy to demanding. The more challenging problems need also knowledge from different domains (XSLT, CSS, etc.)

The topics are mostly based on my own experiences with DocBook and the DocBook XSL stylesheets. However, it also includes questions and answers from other sources: mostly the DocBook mailinglists, but also other sites that I have found. It is the nature of such topics that there might be some overlap with other sources. When other authors inspired me, I have included their names. If you think your name is missing, please let me know.

As I have learned (and still do) a lot from the masters of DocBook, it is time to give something back. What you are reading is the first draft of the fruits of these efforts. Currently, this book is available under a Creative Commons license (see if you want to know more). I hope you enjoy reading this book as much as I enjoy writing it.

section.title: Audience
section.para: This book covers topics which range from very easy to pretty demanding. The more challenging problems need also knowledge from different domains (CSS, FO, XSLT, etc.) As such, this book does not and cannot attempt to teach you DocBook or any such related technology (with the exception of ). If you want to learn DocBook or need some help with XML, search elsewhere. There are plenty of information available either online or printed.

This book is aimed at DocBook users who write and seek answers for their problems. However, with some try-and-error it can also be useful for ordinary writers who wants to customize their documents. For readers who want further information are some links included in the See Also section at the end of each topic.

section.title: Further Readings
section.para: By no means is this book complete. As this book is based on technologies like CSS, XML, (X)HTML, and XSLT, it is always a good idea to seek other information. I highly recommend to read the books from Norman Walsh and Bob Stayton as mentioned above.

section.title: Typographical Conventions
section.para: The following typographical conventions are used in this book:

listitem.para: Italic is used for definition of new terms or emphasised text.
Monospace text is used for code listings, URLs, filenames, namespaces, or links.
Monospace bold text for commands or emphasised text in listings.
Monospace italic text is used for placeholders in listings.
